results_summary: The review found significant overlap in themes covered but noted gaps in newer topics like sexuality and gender-specific issues. Patient involvement in intervention development was rare, and definitions of psychoeducation varied.
population_specificity: Adults with ADHD, primarily in Europe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize currently registered trials examining interventions for mental health, cognition, and psychological wellbeing in patients with long COVID.
results_summary: The review identified 42 registered trials, including 11 psychological interventions, but noted the breadth and scope of research remains limited, with most trials being feasibility studies evaluating a wide spectrum of outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with long COVID experiencing mental health, cognition, and psychological wellbeing impacts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of psychosocial interventions in reducing antipsychotic medication use among care home residents with behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD).
results_summary: The study found mixed results on the effectiveness of psychosocial interventions in reducing antipsychotic prescriptions, with some interventions showing potential benefits while others showed no clear effect. High-certainty evidence indicated little to no difference in adverse events, quality of life, or other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Care home residents with behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of PUFA supplementation in managing ADHD and provide guidance to healthcare professionals on its use.
results_summary: The panel concluded that PUFA supplementation has a small beneficial effect on behavior in children with ADHD but should not replace treatments with stronger evidence. Further high-quality research is needed to define its role.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and adults with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychosocial support interventions in improving patient survival and identify moderating factors associated with greater effectiveness.
results_summary: Psychosocial interventions promoting health behaviors improved survival likelihood (OR = 1.20), while those focusing on social/emotional outcomes did not. Survival time improved (HR = 1.29), but effects were weaker in control groups receiving additional health information and among patients with greater disease severity.
population_specificity: 40,280 patients (52% female, 48% male; average age 57.2 years) with cardiovascular disease (42%), cancer (36%), or other conditions (22%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of pharmacotherapy (specifically SSRIs and buspirone) on treating anxiety disorders in individuals with comorbid alcohol use disorders, evaluating efficacy, tolerability, and alcohol use outcomes.
results_summary: The evidence for medication efficacy was limited and of very low quality, with some indication that paroxetine and buspirone may reduce anxiety symptoms but no significant effect on alcohol use. High dropout rates and common adverse effects (e.g., sexual problems with SSRIs) were noted.
population_specificity: Individuals with comorbid anxiety disorders (PTSD, SAD, GAD) and alcohol use disorders, predominantly male (70%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Guided Self-Determination adapted for schizophrenia (GSD-SZ) improved insight, symptom severity, and social functioning in outpatients with schizophrenia when added to treatment as usual (TAU).
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in cognitive insight with GSD-SZ+TAU, but at 12-month follow-up, clinical insight, symptom severity, and social functioning showed statistically significant improvements compared to TAU alone.
population_specificity: Outpatients diagnosed with schizophrenia.
study_duration: 12 months (with assessments at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and evaluate the antidiabetic potential of vildagliptin-loaded core-shell nanoparticles of grafted psyllium and alginate (VG@P/A-NPs).
results_summary: The study found that VG@P/A-NPs significantly increased glucose uptake in an insulin-resistant cell model, with no observed cytotoxicity. The drug release was highest at pH 7.4, following a diffusion-controlled process.
population_specificity: Human lung adenocarcinoma cell line A549 and mouse muscle L6 cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of psyllium in treating cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs) such as hyperlipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, hyperuricemia, and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium exhibits multiple therapeutic effects, including antioxidant, anti-tumor, antidiabetic, hypotensive, anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, antidiarrheal, and antiviral activities, with potential benefits for CMDs.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of available studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of psyllium husk on volatile fatty acid (VFA) production in the canine intestinal microbiome compared to lactulose.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly increased total VFA concentrations in dog feces by day 15, with elevated acetate, propionate, and n-butyrate levels, suggesting it enhances intestinal fermentation. The effects were slightly delayed compared to lactulose but demonstrated distinct benefits, particularly in n-butyrate production.
population_specificity: Thirty dogs on a standard diet.
effective_dosage: 0.2 g/kg body weight, administered in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Psyllium husk fiber, alone and combined with lifestyle modification, on insulin resistance and fasting blood glucose in centrally obese individuals.
results_summary: The combined intervention of Psyllium husk fiber and lifestyle modification showed the highest reduction in fasting blood glucose (-9%) and HOMA-IR (-58%), followed by Psyllium alone (-7% and -33%, respectively). Both interventions had statistically significant effects (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Centrally obese school teachers (aged 40-60 years) with no chronic disease history in Malakand, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate psyllium husk as a high-temperature-resistant and environmentally friendly filtrate reducer in water-based drilling fluids.
results_summary: Psyllium husk improved rheological and fluid loss properties of bentonite-based slurry, with temperature resistance up to 160°C, reducing API fluid loss by 76.04% and high-temperature/high-pressure fluid loss by 56.91%. Its branched structure and uronic acid inhibited molecular degradation, maintaining performance at high temperatures.
population_specificity: Bentonite-based slurry (industrial application, not human subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (evaluated after hot rolling at 160°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 3-month supplementation with 15 g of psyllium daily affects micronutrient status in overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: No significant differences in serum micronutrient concentrations were found between psyllium and control groups after 3 months. However, dietary intake of folate, sodium, zinc, and magnesium decreased in the psyllium group.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (BMI 25-40 kg/m², aged 18-65 years) who were otherwise healthy.
effective_dosage: 5 g sachet three times daily (total 15 g/day).
study_duration: 3 months (data analyzed from a larger 52-week study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of swimming training and Plantago psyllium on learning, memory impairment, and glucose tolerance in type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that co-administration of swimming training and P. psyllium improved memory deficits, glucose tolerance, and lipid profiles in diabetic rats, with significant improvements in cognitive tests compared to untreated diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-nicotinamide-induced type 2 diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: Mixed with standard pelleted food at a weight ratio of 5%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of early oral fiber administration (timothy hay and psyllium) on growth and hindgut environment in preweaning calves.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium and timothy hay administration increased body weight at 21 days, altered fecal microbiota (higher beneficial bacteria, lower pathogenic bacteria), and had no adverse effects on health or growth. Fecal fermentation parameters were mostly unaffected, except for higher propionate at 7 days.
population_specificity: Newborn female Holstein calves (preweaning stage).
effective_dosage: 50 g/day from days 3-7, then 100 g/day until weaning.
study_duration: From 3 days of age until weaning (56 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biomedical applications of psyllium, alginate, and their engineered interpenetrating polymer network (IPN) structures, focusing on synthesis, structural properties, and potential uses in drug delivery, wound dressing, and tissue engineering.
results_summary: The study highlights psyllium's potential in biomedical applications, such as sustained drug delivery, wound dressing, and tissue engineering, due to its improved swelling ability, biodegradability, biocompatibility, and cost-effectiveness. Further research is suggested to develop psyllium-based IPNs for treating life-threatening diseases, leveraging its inherent pharmacological properties like hypoglycemic, immunomodulatory, antineoplastic, and antimicrobial effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if coadministering psyllium with inulin reduces gas production in patients with IBS, compared to inulin alone.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly reduced inulin-related gas production in IBS patients, delaying and reducing the maximum increase in breath hydrogen. However, psyllium did not directly inhibit fermentation in vitro.
population_specificity: 19 patients with IBS

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effects and potential mechanisms of psyllium husk in alleviating constipation in women of reproductive age, focusing on gut microbiota changes.
results_summary: Psyllium husk relieved constipation symptoms and altered gut microbiota composition, with enriched metabolic pathways compared to placebo. Network analysis showed stronger microbial correlations in the psyllium group.
population_specificity: Constipated women of reproductive age (n=25 psyllium, n=29 placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of psyllium, kiwifruit, and prunes in treating chronic constipation (CC) in US patients.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly improved weekly complete spontaneous bowel movements (CSBMs) and straining but had the highest rate of adverse events among the treatments. Patient dissatisfaction with psyllium was higher compared to kiwifruit.
population_specificity: US adults with chronic constipation (mean age 42.7 years, 87% female, 77% white).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of powdered *Plantago ovata* (Psyllium) and silver sulfadiazine (SSD) 1% in promoting second-degree burn wound healing in rats.
results_summary: Psyllium showed better wound healing (60% complete healing) compared to SSD (50%) and the control group (20%), with significant improvement over the control but no significant difference between Psyllium and SSD.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with second-degree burns.
effective_dosage: Powdered *P. ovata* applied daily (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if psyllium supplementation increases fecal sand passage and alters hindgut bacterial populations in horses.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation decreased fecal ADF concentration in mature mares during and just after treatment but did not affect silica levels. Microbial diversity peaked mid-supplementation and declined post-treatment, with some functional benefits observed.
population_specificity: Six yearlings and six mature mares

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of psyllium husk (PH) on gut microbiota, colonic gene expression, histopathology, and immune responses in a DSS-induced colitis mouse model.
results_summary: Psyllium husk increased gene expression of tight junction proteins (claudins and occludin) and reduced disease activity index (DAI) in DSS-treated mice, suggesting protective effects against colitis. However, it did not significantly alter gut microbiota richness or immune cell populations compared to controls.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice with DSS-induced colitis.
study_duration: 2 weeks of diet adaptation followed by 5 days of DSS treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the hepatoprotective effect of Plantago psyllium L. seed extract against carbon tetrachloride-induced hepatotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Psyllium seed extract significantly alleviated CCl4-induced hepatotoxicity by restoring liver biomarkers, normalizing oxidative stress markers (lipid peroxidation, glutathione, catalase), and reducing TNF-α expression. Histopathological findings confirmed the protective effect on liver architecture.
population_specificity: Male albino Wistar rats (10 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a product containing probiotics, prebiotics, and psyllium in clearing colonic sand in horses with naturally acquired sand accumulation.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in sand accumulation in both treatment and control groups, but no significant differences between the groups in sand clearance as measured by fecal sand sedimentation and radiography.
population_specificity: Horses with naturally acquired sand accumulation in the colon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effect of psyllium supplementation on blood pressure in hypertensive patients through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant reduction of 2.04 mmHg in systolic blood pressure, with stronger effects in subjects with higher baseline blood pressure. The study concluded that psyllium supplementation is beneficial for hypertensive patients with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients (592 participants across 11 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of psyllium consumption on weight, BMI, lipid profiles, and glucose metabolism in diabetic patients through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Psyllium consumption significantly reduced triglycerides, LDL, fasting blood sugar, and hemoglobin A1c in diabetic patients, but showed no significant changes in HDL, BMI, cholesterol, or weight.
population_specificity: Adult diabetic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium and coarse wheat bran on stool output and stool water content in patients with chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC) and address misconceptions about fiber in treatment guidelines.
results_summary: Psyllium was 3.4 times more effective than insoluble wheat bran for increasing stool output in CIC patients. Both psyllium and coarse wheat bran increased stool water content, while finely ground wheat bran decreased it.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of psyllium, alone or combined with lactitol, on bowel function in adults with functional constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium increased bowel movement frequency by 2.9 BMs, similar to lactitol and the combination, but not significantly different from placebo. No serious adverse events were reported, and treatments were well tolerated.
population_specificity: Adults (N = 172) diagnosed with functional constipation per Rome III criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psyllium seed husk (PSH) could inhibit the progression of vascular dementia (VaD) by attenuating white matter damage in a rat model.
results_summary: PSH supplementation reduced astrocytic and microglial activation, attenuated white matter damage, improved pupillary light reflex, and enhanced glial cell survival under hypoxic and glucose-deprived conditions. These effects suggest PSH may inhibit VaD progression due to its high arabinoxylan content.
population_specificity: Rats with bilateral common carotid artery occlusion (a model of vascular dementia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of psyllium on fecal microbiota, gastrointestinal transit, fecal water content, and short-chain fatty acid levels in healthy volunteers and constipated patients.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly altered microbial composition, increased fecal water content, and affected short-chain fatty acid levels, with more pronounced effects in constipated patients. Several butyrate-producing genera increased, correlating with higher fecal water content.
population_specificity: 8 healthy volunteers and 16 constipated patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Psyllium as a laxative, particularly focusing on the risks of intestinal obstruction when taken without adequate fluids.
results_summary: The study found that Psyllium is generally safe and effective for treating constipation but can cause intestinal obstruction if ingested without sufficient fluids. Similar adverse effects have been reported in elderly patients and post-operative cases.
population_specificity: 21-year-old man with constipation, with additional context provided for elderly patients and post-gastric banding cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium versus flaxseed and placebo on constipation symptoms, weight, glycemic control, and lipid levels in constipated patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly improved constipation symptoms, stool consistency, weight, BMI, fasting plasma glucose, cholesterol, LDL-C, and cholesterol/HDL-C ratio compared to placebo, though flaxseed showed superior effects. Compliance was good, and no adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: Constipated patients with type 2 diabetes (n=77).
effective_dosage: 10 g psyllium pre-mixed in cookies, twice per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psyllium supplementation in standard enteral nutrition reduces the incidence of diarrhea in tube-fed patients.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation showed no significant benefit in reducing diarrhea incidence or improving stool frequency/scores compared to the control group. The proportion of patients with diarrhea and median diarrhea scores were similar between groups.
population_specificity: General medical ward patients expected to receive enteral nutrition for ≥5 days, excluding those with hemodynamic instability, significant gastrointestinal problems, or recent pancreatitis.
effective_dosage: 15.2 g/L of psyllium (Mucilin SF) added to the enteral formula.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence on psyllium's effect on LDL cholesterol and assess its impact on non-HDL cholesterol and apolipoprotein B (apoB) as alternative markers.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly reduced LDL cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, and apoB, with effect estimates graded as moderate to high quality, suggesting it effectively improves lipid markers.
population_specificity: Individuals with or without hypercholesterolemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a combination of psyllium and magnesium sulphate for removing large colonic sand accumulations in horses without acute colic.
results_summary: The treated group showed significantly greater clearance of sand accumulations compared to the control group, as measured by radiographic evaluation and successful treatment rates (P<0.001 and P=0.004, respectively), though individual variations in clearance were noted.
population_specificity: Horses without clinical signs of acute colic but with large colonic sand accumulations.
effective_dosage: 1g/kg bodyweight of psyllium and 1g/kg bodyweight of MgSO4, administered once daily via nasogastric intubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding psyllium fiber to statin therapy would further lower cholesterol levels compared to statin use alone.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that psyllium plus statin significantly lowered cholesterol more than statin alone (p = 0.001), with reductions in LDL-C equivalent to doubling the statin dose. Psyllium provided an effective dietary intervention for those intolerant to higher statin doses.
population_specificity: Subjects already receiving statins (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the utility of MRI in evaluating the mode of action of psyllium as a treatment for constipation by assessing its effects on intestinal fluid content and colonic volume.
results_summary: Psyllium at 7 g t.d.s. significantly increased fasting colonic volumes in both controls and patients with chronic constipation, improved postprandial small bowel water content, and altered descending colon T1, correlating with stool water content and frequency.
population_specificity: Adults without constipation (controls, n=9) and adults with chronic constipation (patients, n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential risks of pelleted psyllium products in horses, specifically focusing on gastric impaction and obstruction.
results_summary: The study found that a mare developed gastric rupture due to duodenal obstruction caused by psyllium bezoars after receiving 4 times the recommended dosage of pelleted psyllium. It suggests that excessive psyllium use in horses may lead to severe gastrointestinal complications.
population_specificity: Horses (specifically a mare with colic)
effective_dosage: 4 times the recommended dosage (exact amount not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Psyllium seed and oral omeprazole on GERD symptoms and recurrence in patients with functional constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium seed showed a high treatment response rate (89.2%) and significantly lower recurrence rate (24.1%) compared to omeprazole (94% response, 69.8% recurrence). The results suggest Psyllium is effective for improving GERD symptoms and reducing recurrence in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with GERD and functional constipation (n=132).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hydrogel scaffold made from psyllium seed husk polysaccharide (PSH), human hair keratins (KER), and morin (MOR) in promoting diabetic wound healing.
results_summary: The PSH + KER + MOR scaffold significantly reduced re-epithelialization time and enhanced wound contraction in diabetic rats by accelerating collagen synthesis. The scaffold also demonstrated high porosity, fluid absorption capacity, and supported fibroblast cell viability after 48 hours.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats with chronic wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a synthesized adsorbent based on Gum xanthan-psyllium hybrid backbone for removing auramine-O and eriochrome black-T dyes from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The adsorbent demonstrated high dye removal efficiency (90.53% for EBT and 95.63% for Aur-O) under specified conditions, followed Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms, and exhibited good recyclability with minimal activity decline after multiple cycles.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions contaminated with dyes (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a moderate carbohydrate diet with psyllium supplementation versus a lower carbohydrate diet with placebo on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly reduced fasting plasma insulin and TNF-α levels and improved insulin sensitivity (HOMA-IR) compared to placebo, though no significant effects were observed on fasting plasma glucose or postprandial measures.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (BMI 25-35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Plantago psyllium (PP) and Ocimum basilicum (OB) on anthropometric measurements in individuals with hepatic steatosis.
results_summary: The study found that Psyllium (PP) and its combination with OB led to significant reductions in weight, BMI, soft lean mass, and lean body mass within groups, but no significant differences were observed between groups. The study concluded that Psyllium did not significantly affect anthropometric measures in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of psyllium fiber in reducing abdominal pain and improving stool patterns in children with IBS, while also assessing its effects on gut permeability, microbiome composition, and psychological factors.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly reduced the number of abdominal pain episodes compared to placebo but did not affect pain intensity, stool consistency, breath hydrogen/methane production, gut permeability, or microbiome composition. Psychological factors did not influence treatment response.
population_specificity: Children (mean age 13 ± 3 years) with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) from primary or tertiary care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of three treatment protocols, including psyllium, in clearing colonic sand accumulations in horses.
results_summary: Daily nasogastric tubing with psyllium and/or magnesium sulfate for 3-7 days was more effective at removing large sand accumulations than feeding psyllium for at least 10 days. Group 3 (nasogastric tubing) had significantly less residual sand and a higher proportion of resolved cases compared to Groups 1 and 2.
population_specificity: Horses and ponies with colonic sand accumulations (n=246).
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg body weight daily (psyllium), sometimes combined with magnesium sulfate.
study_duration: 3-7 days (Group 3) or at least 10 days (Groups 1 and 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of psyllium on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and those at risk of developing T2DM.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly improved fasting blood glucose (-37.0 mg/dL) and glycated hemoglobin (-0.97%) in T2DM patients, with effects proportional to baseline glucose levels. No significant glucose lowering was observed in euglycemic subjects, while modest improvements were seen in pre-T2DM subjects.
population_specificity: Nondiabetic, pre-T2DM, and T2DM patients.
effective_dosage: Dosed before meals (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Plantago psyllium supplementation on LDL and HDL subclasses and IL-6 levels in obese adolescents to assess its potential for reducing cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: The study found that Plantago psyllium significantly reduced small-dense LDL (sdLDL) and IL-6 levels in obese adolescents, with no differences in HDL subclasses and no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Obese adolescents aged 15-19 with a BMI of 29-34.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and tolerability of psyllium versus loperamide in reducing fecal incontinence episodes and improving symptom severity and quality of life.
results_summary: Psyllium was found to be as effective as loperamide in reducing fecal incontinence episodes and improving symptom severity and quality of life, with fewer adverse effects (10% constipation rate for psyllium vs. 29% for loperamide).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults (n=80, mean age 60.7 ± 10.1 years, 68% men) with at least one fecal incontinence episode in a 7-day bowel diary.
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention phase, with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Psyllium fiber in improving residual constipation and defecation urgency after surgery for obstructed defecation.
results_summary: Psyllium fiber significantly reduced constipation and defecation urgency at both 1 week and 6 months post-surgery, with better outcomes in the treatment group compared to placebo. It also improved fecal incontinence scores.
population_specificity: 65 patients who underwent surgery for obstructed defecation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the LDL-cholesterol-lowering effects and safety of psyllium in dyslipidaemic children and adolescents.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol (7.7%) and LDL-C (10.7%) compared to the control group, with no reported adverse effects or participant aversion. The therapy was deemed safe and acceptable for hypercholesterolaemic children and adolescents.
population_specificity: Brazilian dyslipidaemic children and adolescents (6-19 years) with mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of psyllium, magnesium sulphate (MgSO4), and their combination in evacuating large sand accumulations in the large colon of horses.
results_summary: Psyllium alone resolved sand accumulation in 3/12 horses, while the combination of psyllium and MgSO4 was significantly more effective, resolving it in 9/12 horses. Psyllium was less effective than the combination but showed some efficacy compared to MgSO4 alone (2/10 horses).
population_specificity: Adult horses with naturally acquired large sand accumulations (>5 cm × 15 cm) in the large colon.
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg psyllium administered once daily via nasogastric intubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the beneficial effects of psyllium on lipid metabolism and gene expression in liver and skeletal muscle, particularly in the context of high-fat diets.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly reduced plasma total cholesterol, TAG, and blood glucose levels, decreased adipose tissue weight, and up-regulated genes involved in fatty acid oxidation and lipid transport in skeletal muscle. These findings suggest psyllium promotes lipid consumption in muscle and may create a glucose-deficient state in the liver.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice fed low-fat or high-fat diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if psyllium supplementation improves glycemic control indicators and body weight in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly reduced BMI, fasting blood sugar, HbA1c, insulin levels, C-peptide, HOMA-IR, and improved HOMA-β% compared to the control group. The study concluded that soluble fiber enhances glycemic response and may improve glucose metabolism in type 2 diabetes patients.
population_specificity: 40 non-smoking type 2 diabetes patients aged >35 years, stratified by sex, age, BMI, and fasting blood sugar levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the prebiotic and hypolipidemic effects of a 12-week psyllium treatment in patients with uncomplicated diverticular disease and hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: Psyllium normalized intestinal motility, reduced pain and flatulence, increased short-chain fatty acids in feces, lowered the anaerobic index, and significantly reduced hyperlipidemia levels. It was deemed suitable for monotherapy in cases where baseline cholesterol was below 6.4 mmol/l.
population_specificity: Patients with uncomplicated diverticular disease and hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of a psyllium-containing fiber mixture (AFPFF) with PEG+E in treating chronic functional constipation in children.
results_summary: Both AFPFF and PEG+E significantly improved constipation symptoms, with 77.8% and 83% of children showing improvement, respectively, and no clinically significant side effects were reported.
population_specificity: 100 children (aged 6.5 ± 2.7 years) diagnosed with chronic functional constipation.
effective_dosage: 16.8 g daily of AFPFF (containing psyllium fiber).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of psyllium supplementation on insulin sensitivity and metabolic syndrome parameters in at-risk adolescent males.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation (6 g/day for 6 weeks) led to a 4% reduction in android-to-gynoid fat ratio and a 6% reduction in LDL cholesterol, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: 45 healthy adolescent males aged 15-16 years from lower socio-economic areas with high obesity rates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a psyllium-enriched diet for managing constipation in cats.
results_summary: The psyllium-enriched diet was well tolerated and improved fecal consistency in most cats, with significant reductions in the need for additional therapies like cisapride and lactulose. Improvement rates were high (93% in trial 1, 82% in trial 2).
population_specificity: Cats with constipation (66 total: 15 in trial 1, 51 in trial 2).
effective_dosage: Not specified (moderate fiber, psyllium-enriched dry extruded diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium fibre supplementation versus a healthy diet on blood pressure and vascular function in overweight and obese adults over 12 weeks.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation showed short-term improvements in blood pressure and vascular function at week 6, but these effects did not persist by week 12. A healthy diet provided more sustained improvements in blood pressure compared to psyllium supplementation.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of psyllium husk as a coagulant and coagulant aid for treating landfill leachate, comparing its effectiveness with poly-aluminum chloride (PACl) and aluminum sulfate (alum).
results_summary: Psyllium husk was more effective as a coagulant aid with PACl, achieving maximum removal efficiencies of 64% for COD, 90% for color, and 96% for TSS, outperforming alum. The study also conducted zeta potential tests to enhance jar test results.
population_specificity: Landfill leachate (industrial and domestic waste-derived liquid).
effective_dosage: 7.5 g/L for PACl (primary coagulant), 11 g/L for alum (primary coagulant).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of psyllium versus dried plums in treating chronic constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium improved stool consistency but was less effective than dried plums in increasing complete spontaneous bowel movements. Both treatments were equally safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: 40 constipated subjects (3 male, 37 female, mean age 38 years).
study_duration: 3 weeks per treatment with a 1-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness of psyllium during rehabilitation for obstructed defecation compared to a high-fiber diet.
results_summary: Psyllium improved the obstructed defecation syndrome (ODS) score and conscious rectal sensitivity threshold (CRST), with patients on psyllium showing lower post-rehabilitative CRST values and shorter volumetric rehabilitation duration than those on a high-fiber diet. Both groups showed significant improvements in stool form and ODS scores, but psyllium was particularly effective for volumetric rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 45 women (aged 25-71) with obstructed defecation.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (study period: January 2008 to December 2010).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and summarize the evidence on the effectiveness of psyllium supplementation for treating symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The review found limited and conflicting evidence supporting psyllium for IBS symptom relief, with 75% of studies being of weak quality. While some studies reported improvements in global symptoms and abdominal pain, others showed no significant benefits, and quality of life and flatulence did not improve in any studies.
population_specificity: Patients with diagnosed irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psyllium inclusion in milk replacer improves nutrient utilization and gastrointestinal function in neonatal calves.
results_summary: Psyllium increased digesta viscosity and slowed gastrointestinal passage but did not significantly affect daily weight gain or most nutrient digestibilities. Total-tract apparent digestibility of dry matter was slightly lower with psyllium.
population_specificity: Male Holstein calves (neonatal, 2 to 28 days old).
effective_dosage: 1.1% of dry matter in milk replacer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of psyllium in improving metabolic syndrome (MS) markers, including cholesterol, blood pressure, glucose levels, and body weight.
results_summary: Psyllium was found to lower serum and liver cholesterol, increase HDL-cholesterol, moderate postprandial glucose and insulin levels, and support body weight reduction and hypertension management. The abstract also highlights psyllium's broader benefits in treating MS.
population_specificity: Non-insulin dependent diabetic patients and individuals at risk of metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psyllium inclusion in milk replacer would enhance gastrointestinal tract (GIT) mass, fermentation, and microbial populations in neonatal dairy calves, potentially improving growth and health.
results_summary: Psyllium increased butyrate proportion in the reticulo-rumen, boosted total VFA concentrations in the colon, enhanced bifidobacteria and lactobacilli populations in the reticulo-rumen, and significantly increased GIT mass and intestinal tissue density.
population_specificity: Male Holstein dairy calves (2 to 28 days old).
effective_dosage: 1.1% of dry matter (DM) in milk replacer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of replacing gluten with psyllium on the sensory, chemical, nutritional, and technological characteristics of bread dough.
results_summary: Modified psyllium dough achieved high acceptance rates (93.0% for celiac individuals, 97.0% for non-celiac individuals), with reduced energy (32.1%) and fat (42.3%) content. Sensory analysis indicated good acceptance, suggesting psyllium can effectively replace gluten.
population_specificity: Individuals with and without celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether psyllium fiber could serve as a safe and effective therapeutic strategy for functional constipation in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that psyllium fiber may achieve good results in managing functional constipation, though specific efficacy metrics are not detailed. The abstract implies positive outcomes without providing statistical or clinical data.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of psyllium on metabolic control, lipoprotein profile, and postprandial lipids in type II diabetic patients.
results_summary: Psyllium treatment significantly reduced triglycerides in diabetic patients but showed no postprandial differences in lipoprotein profile compared to dietary measures alone. Both groups experienced improvements in body mass index, waist circumference, HbA1c, and fasting plasma glucose.
population_specificity: 40 type II diabetic patients on sulfonylureas and a controlled diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of psyllium seed husk on fecal bifidobacteria in healthy women and its in vitro metabolism by bifidobacteria.
results_summary: Psyllium seed husk did not significantly affect average fecal bifidobacteria levels overall, but increased counts in women with initially low levels. In vitro, bifidobacteria could metabolize psyllium only after partial hydrolysis.
population_specificity: Healthy women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose-response relationship and long-term lipid-lowering efficacy of psyllium in mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolemic subjects.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly lowered serum total cholesterol by 0.375 mmol/l and LDL cholesterol by 0.278 mmol/l compared to placebo, with dose- and time-dependent effects observed. Higher doses and longer treatment periods resulted in greater reductions in cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolemic subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ball milling could enhance the water extractability and molecular mass of arabinoxylan (AX) in Psyllium seed husk (PSH).
results_summary: Ball milling significantly reduced particle size, increased water-extractable AX levels from 13% to 90%, and altered molecular mass and viscosity. Impact and jet milling had minimal effects on AX extractability compared to ball milling.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-scale study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if psyllium husk's limited use for hypercholesterolemia in Germany is due to adverse gastrointestinal effects and to assess its cholesterol-lowering efficacy.
results_summary: Psyllium husk significantly reduced total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol levels, while gastrointestinal symptoms decreased over time, though some patients experienced transient adverse reactions.
population_specificity: 62 outpatients with hypercholesterolemia and constipation from an academic clinical center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily psyllium fiber supplementation would reduce inflammatory markers (hsCRP, IL-6, fibrinogen, WBC count) in overweight or obese adults.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation did not significantly reduce hsCRP levels, and changes in other inflammatory markers were inconsistent. A small decrease in fibrinogen was observed in the high-fiber group among protocol completers, but no other significant differences were found.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults with no history of heart disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of psyllium combined with mineral oil versus mineral oil alone in evacuating sand from the equine intestine.
results_summary: All horses showed significantly higher crude ash excretion when treated with psyllium and mineral oil compared to mineral oil alone, with the difference being statistically significant on days 2-4 of treatment. The combined treatment resulted in a mean ash output of 51.0% of administered sand mass, versus 26.1% with mineral oil alone.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy horses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the lipid-lowering mechanisms of combined psyllium and plant sterols in hypercholesterolemic individuals.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium and plant sterols significantly reduced LDL cholesterol, modified lipoprotein processing, and increased LDL receptor-mediated uptake. It also decreased smaller LDL and HDL subfractions and altered LDL peak size and pattern prevalence.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolemic individuals (n = 33)
effective_dosage: 7.28 g psyllium and 2 g plant sterols per day, administered via 2 test cookies
study_duration: 1 month per treatment period with a 3-week washout
